title: What’s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the perception of a noise like ringing, buzzing, hissing, or clicking that occurs without any external source of sound?
According to the transcript, what percentage of people worldwide experience tinnitus?
Where do the nerve signals that produce tinnitus sounds typically originate?
What is the purpose of the background neural activity in the hearing pathway?

options.label: B
options.text: To distinguish between silence and sound

multiple-choice.question: What can damage cochlear cells and lead to tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: Loud noises, diseases, toxins, and aging

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the type of tinnitus that accounts for the vast majority of cases?
What is the effect of increasing background neural activity in the hearing pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the perception of sound

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the perception of sound

options.label: C
options.text: It modifies the baseline for silence

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition where tinnitus episodes trigger traumatic memories or distressing feelings?
What is the purpose of sound therapy in treating tinnitus?

options.label: B
options.text: To mask tinnitus and reduce stress

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the type of sound therapy that uses sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal?

title: Can you outsmart the fallacy that fooled a generation of doctors? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: In the 19th century, what was one of the most common killers of women, especially within days of giving birth?
According to Charles Meigs, what was the cause of childbed fever?
What fallacy is Charles Meigs' argument based on?
What is the main idea behind the false cause fallacy?

options.label: C
options.text: Cause and effect are always direct

options.label: D
options.text: There is no such thing as coincidence

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Direct causation, indirect causation, and no causation

options.label: C
options.text: Inflammation causes fever, fever causes inflammation, and both are unrelated

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Ignaz Semmelweis' initiative?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: The number of childbed fever deaths decreased from 1% to 0%

title: The greatest mathematician that never lived - Pratik Aghor

multiple-choice.question: Who is Nicolas Bourbaki?

options.label: A
options.text: A French mathematician who made significant contributions to the field of mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: A collective pseudonym used by a group of French mathematicians.

options.label: C
options.text: A Russian mathematician who published numerous articles and textbooks.

options.label: D
options.text: A mathematician who lost his life in World War I.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the rejection of Nicolas Bourbaki's application to the American Mathematical Society?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of publications in international journals.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of the "Éléments de mathématique" treatise?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a comprehensive textbook for calculus.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: To introduce new mathematical objects and definitions.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a systematic approach to abstract principles.

multiple-choice.question: How did the group define a function?

options.label: A
options.text: As a machine that accepts inputs and produces an output.

options.label: B
options.text: As a bridge between two groups that establishes logical relationships.

options.label: C
options.text: As a mathematical object with a unique input and output.

options.label: D
options.text: As a process that maps elements across domains.

multiple-choice.question: What type of function is defined as having a unique input for every output?
What was the popular belief about mathematics that the group challenged?

options.label: A
options.text: That mathematics is a rigorous and systematic field.

options.label: B
options.text: That mathematics is an intuitive science and an over-dependence on logic constrains creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: That mathematics is a fragmented field with disparate methodologies.

options.label: D
options.text: That mathematics is a field that requires a shared language.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the group decide to publish their work under a collective pseudonym?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark the occasion of their revolutionary work.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a consistent logical framework.

multiple-choice.question: How did the group maintain the ruse of Nicolas Bourbaki's existence?

options.label: A
options.text: By publishing articles and textbooks under his name.

options.label: B
options.text: By sending telegrams and announcing his daughter's wedding.

options.label: C
options.text: By claiming he was a reclusive Russian genius.

multiple-choice.question: What is the legacy of Nicolas Bourbaki?

options.label: A
options.text: A single major discovery that revolutionized the field of mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: A rigorous and systematic approach to mathematics that informs current research.

options.label: D
options.text: A fragmented field with disparate methodologies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the group bearing Nicolas Bourbaki's name?

options.label: A
options.text: The group disbanded after the ruse was revealed.

options.label: B
options.text: The group continues to publish articles and textbooks under Nicolas Bourbaki's name.

options.label: C
options.text: The group's influence has diminished over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The group lives on today, and their work continues to inform current research.

title: What do all languages have in common? - Cameron Morin

multiple-choice.question: Who proposed the theory of universal grammar in the early 1950s?

options.text: Grammar rules are innate and universal to all languages

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Language is not acquired, but rather innate

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the development of a new theory of language acquisition

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the discovery of a new language

title: First person vs. Second person vs. Third person - Rebekah Bergman

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary effect of changing the point of view in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: It only affects the tone of the narrative.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the plot.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of narrative is characterized by the narrator being outside the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrator has access to all characters' thoughts.

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator is limited to their own knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator can only describe the setting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary effect of using a plural first-person narrator, as seen in Justin Torres's novel "We the Animals"?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates distance between the reader and the narrator.

options.label: B
options.text: It builds suspense by limiting the narrator's knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: It emphasizes the collective experience of the characters.

options.label: D
options.text: It restricts the narrator to a single character's thoughts.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using a third-person limited narrator?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the reader to access all characters' thoughts.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a sense of distance between the reader and the characters.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps focus the story on a single character's experience.

options.label: D
options.text: It eliminates suspense by providing too much information.

multiple-choice.question: How does the use of second-person narration in a story typically affect the reader?

options.label: A
options.text: It distances the reader from the narrative.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires the reader to suspend disbelief and become the character.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides the reader with more information about the characters.

options.label: D
options.text: It limits the reader's access to the narrator's thoughts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary effect of using an unreliable first-person narrator, as seen in Kazuo Ishiguro's novel "The Remains of the Day"?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of closeness between the reader and the narrator.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides the reader with a biased perspective on the events.

options.label: C
options.text: It eliminates suspense by revealing all information.

options.label: D
options.text: It restricts the narrator to a single character's thoughts.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They will expand the possibilities for experimentation with point of view.

options.label: D
options.text: They will only affect the setting of stories.

options.label: B
options.text: The tone they want to convey.

options.label: C
options.text: The constraints and possibilities of each point of view.

multiple-choice.question: How does the use of a first-person narrator affect the reader's experience of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of distance between the reader and the narrator.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides the reader with more information about the characters.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sense of closeness between the reader and the narrator.

options.label: D

title: What can DNA tests really tell us about our ancestry? - Prosanta Chakrabarty

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the human genome is shared among all humans?

options.text: Because they have different numbers of genes

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they do not account for the complexity of human identity

title: When is a pandemic over?

options.label: B

options.text: The strategy may not work if people can be reinfected.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be short-lived and entirely positive.

options.label: C
options.text: It will be long-lasting, but not all bad.

options.label: D
options.text: It will have no lasting impact.

options.text: The next pandemic will be more severe.

options.label: B
options.text: The next pandemic will be less contained.

options.label: C

options.label: D
